content:
• Thursday, April 25, 2013
  • AMZN

    Amazon's (NASDAQ:AMZN) Q1 Y/Y paid unit growth was 30%, the company discloses in its CC; that's...

    Amazon's (NASDAQ:AMZN) Q1 Y/Y paid unit growth was 30%, the company discloses in its CC; that's down from Q4's 32% and Q3's 39%, but still above rev. growth of 22%. 3rd-party sellers (some of them upset over fee hikes) made up 40% of unit sales vs. 39% in Q4 and 41% in Q3; they've been a major source of gross margin growth. Digital content sales growth slowed down, leading physical units to rise over 300 bps Y/Y as a % of total units. Forex expected to have a 275 bps impact on Q2 rev. growth. North America had a $457M op. profit in Q1, international a $16M op. loss. Active customer accounts rose to 209M+ from 200M+ in Q4.Â  AMZN now -3% AH. (Q1: I, II)

     
     
     
     
    | 7:28 PM | 4 Comments
  • PFE

    The European Medicines Agency has recommended against approval of Pfizer's (NYSE:PFE) new...

    The European Medicines Agency has recommended against approval of Pfizer's (NYSE:PFE) new arthritis drug Xeljanz, which was approved by US FDA last year. Committee cites concerns about drug's efficacy and safety. ISI Group says the European component of Xeljanz represents 25% of sales, and failure to launch there would trim its EPS by up to 3% by 2017. Shares -2.5% AH.

     
     
     
     
    | 7:20 PM

    Spreadtrum (NASDAQ:SPRD) -3.2% AH after announcing it has fired CTO Qiuzhen (Joe) Zhou, and stating it doesn't intend to field a replacement. No explanation is given for the firing, which comes ahead of the Chinese mobile baseband chipmaker's May 9 Q1 report. (PR)

  • MMSI

    More on Merit Medical Systems (NASDAQ:MMSI): Q1 misses on all counts despite a 9% rise in total...

    More on Merit Medical Systems (NASDAQ:MMSI): Q1 misses on all counts despite a 9% rise in total sales. Net income sank Y/Y, primarily to lower gross margins, higher investments in R&D, and increased interest expense. Catheter sales +10%; custom kit and tray sales +7%; Endotek sales +6%; stand-alone device sales +2%; BioSphere sales -5%; and inflation device sales -5%. Gross margins were 41.4% of sales, compared to 46.2% of sales for the prior year period. Shares -9% AH.

    Micros (NASDAQ:MCRS) sinks 7.65% AH as the company guides below Street estimates for both FQ4...

    Micros (NASDAQ:MCRS) sinks 7.65% AH as the company guides below Street estimates for both FQ4 and FY13. The company, whose FQ3 results topped consensus EPS estimates but came up short on the top line, says it now sees non-GAAP EPS of $0.61-0.63 on revenue of $317-333M in FQ4 and non-GAAP EPS of $2.37-2.39 on sales of $1.256- 1.272B for the full year. The Street expects $0.68 per share on 352.12M in sales in FQ4 and $2.42 per share on revenue of 1.31B for FY13. (PR)

  • PKI

    More on PerkinElmer's (NYSE:PKI) Q1: Shares grind 14% lower in late trading after earnings miss...

    More on PerkinElmer's (NYSE:PKI) Q1: Shares grind 14% lower in late trading after earnings miss on the top and bottom line. Adjusted operating profit margins fall to 12.6% from 15.6% in Q1 2012. The company says it experienced "significant headwinds" in Europe and Japan. Adjusted operating income from the Environmental Health segment falls 31.5% Y/Y, while operating profit margins in the unit shed 160 basis points. PKI sees FY13 non-GAAP EPS of $2.00-2.10 — analysts expect $2.29. (PR)

  • WYNN

    Heard during Wynn Resorts' (NASDAQ:WYNN) earnings call: 1) VIP activity in Macau still looks...

    Heard during Wynn Resorts' (NASDAQ:WYNN) earnings call: 1) VIP activity in Macau still looks promising as the firm says it has lined up deals with new junket operators. 2) Despite the forecasts for stellar growth, execs note rivals are keeping Wynn "on its toes" in Macau. 3) Steve Wynn says there is nothing new to do in the business except the basics better. The Wynn translation seems to be the firm needs to hope for an improved economy. 4) On Cotai, mass transit links to Wynn's new casino set up well to keep mass market traffic high. 5) Steve Wynn doesn't seem to be a fan of online gaming at all, but Wynn won't be left behind as it cautiously looks at opportunities. WYNN -0.6% AH. (webcast)

    Tech guidance roundup: 1) Synaptics (SYNA - earnings) expects FQ4 revenue of $190M-$205M, way...

    Tech guidance roundup: 1) Synaptics (SYNA - earnings) expects FQ4 revenue of $190M-$205M, way above a $158.2M consensus. Strong mobile sales +57% Y/Y in FQ3) responsible. 2) Qlik (QLIK - earnings) expects Q2 revenue of $104M-$108M and EPS of -$0.02 to $0.00 vs. a consensus of $104.8M and $0.02. But it also expects 2013 revenue of $471M-$481M and EPs of $0.41-$0.44, mostly above a consensus of $471.9M and $0.40. 3) Altera (ALTR - earnings) expects Q2 revenue to be flat to up 4% Q/Q, below a consensus for 9% growth. SYNA +19.4% AH. QLIK +11.1%. ALTR -1.9%.(Synaptics PR) (Qlik PR) (Altera PR)

  • OUTR

    More on Coinstar (NASDAQ:CSTR): Q1 misses on revenue but beats on a per share basis. Net profit...

    More on Coinstar (NASDAQ:CSTR): Q1 misses on revenue but beats on a per share basis. Net profit fell 58% Y/Y as growth continues to decelerate in its Redbox DVD-rental business and expenses increased. Revenue from Redbox rose just 1%, continuing a trend of slowing revenue growth. Total expenses increased 7.5%, due to an increase in input costs related to higher DVD content purchases and more kiosks installed in H2. The company also says it plans to seek approval from shareholders to change its name to Outerwall Inc. Shares +5.4% AH.

     
     
     
     
    | 4:51 PM
  • INVA

    Theravance (THRX) races 8% higher in late trading. Concurrently with the release of its Q1...

    Theravance (THRX) races 8% higher in late trading. Concurrently with the release of its Q1 report, THRX announces it intends to split into two independent publicly traded companies. One of the companies will remain focused on "biopharmaceutical operations,"while the other will dedicate itself to managing the "late-stage respiratory assets partnered with GlaxoSmithKline." In other words: THRX is creating a separate company to manage Breo Ellipta/Relvar, the COPD inhaled treatment recently recommended for approval in an FDA panel vote.

    More on Republic Services (NYSE:RSG) Q1 misses on its EPS but comes in line on revenue. Net profit slipped 13% as pension-related costs and restructuring charges weighed on bottom line margins. Revenue was flat Y/Y, while operating margin narrowed to 13.7% from 16.5%. Core prices increased 1.2% and fuel recovery fees were up 0.3%, though volumes and revenue from recycling commodities both saw slight declines. Shares +2% AH.

    More on Starbucks' (NASDAQ:SBUX) FQ2: The company reports global comparable store sales grew 6%,...

    More on Starbucks' (NASDAQ:SBUX) FQ2: The company reports global comparable store sales grew 6%, with a 4% increase in traffic and a 2% gain in average ticket price contributing. By region, Europe and Asia showed lighter sales than forecast while the U.S. was in-line. The company added 590 net new stores during the quarter. Operating margin up 180 bps to 15.3% as lower commodity costs kicked in. Guidance for FY13 EPS is set at $2.12-$2.18 vs. $2.06-$2.15 prior and $2.17 consensus. SBUX -1.3% AH. (PR)

    More on Cerner's (NASDAQ:CERN) Q1: Bookings rise 23% Y/Y to $801.6M, an all-time Q1 high. Weakness in low-margin technology resale puts a dent in revenue growth but has no material effect on net income. Total backlog rose 21% Y/Y and 3.7% sequentially to $7.58B. Guidance: Q2 EPS and revenue of $0.66-$0.68 and $705-735M respectively; FY13 EPS and revenue of $2.78-2.83 and $2.95-3.05B respectively. Shares + 2.33% AH. (PR)

    Dow Chemical (DOW +5.3%) has turned the corner, Goldman's Robert Koort says, viewing Q1 results...

    Dow Chemical (DOW +5.3%) has turned the corner, Goldman's Robert Koort says, viewing Q1 results as "very solid considering the lackluster macroeconomic backdrop... the outperformance without macro help supports our thesis that company self-help (cracker restart, restructuring benefits, etc.) is underappreciated and will drive outperformance of consensus estimates."

     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM | 1 Comment
  • BYI

    The number 2 slot machine maker Bally Technologies (BYI +10.5%) is a winner after its Q1 report....

    The number 2 slot machine maker Bally Technologies (BYI +10.5%) is a winner after its Q1 report. The company says "sustained operating improvement" looks set to "continue for the foreseeable future," as revenue climbs 13% and net income rises 39% to a record high. Thanks to "improving products, practical and effective innovation, and solid execution" BYI also lifts its FY2013 guidance to between $3.35-3.45 per share — analysts expect $3.33. (transcript)

     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM
  • UTHR

    United Therapeutics (UTHR -3%) slides after its Q1 EPS results missed Street expectations...

    United Therapeutics (UTHR -3%) slides after its Q1 EPS results missed Street expectations earlier today. Revenue increased by nearly $41M over the prior year the period, with growth in product revenues reflecting the continuing increase in the number of patients being treated, but expenses in both R&D and SG&A pressured bottom line performance.

     
     
     
     
    | 3:46 PM
  • LTM-OLD

    Life Time Fitness (LTM-OLD +7.4%) climbs notably higher after its Q1 beat. The company raised...

    Life Time Fitness (LTM-OLD +7.4%) climbs notably higher after its Q1 beat. The company raised its guidance for FY13 and now says it sees EPS of $2.87-2.95 on sales of $1.205-1.22B for the full year. Analysts expect $2.89 per share on $1.21B in revenue. The beat and raise comes as a relief to investors who watched the stock crater on tepid guidance last quarter. (PR)

    Altisource Portfolio Solutions (ASPS +7.8%) flies after reporting an 8% Y/Y increase in EPS even...

    Altisource Portfolio Solutions (ASPS +7.8%) flies after reporting an 8% Y/Y increase in EPS even with just limited benefit from Ocwen's (NYSE:OCN) acquisition of Homeward Residential's servicing platform and no benefit from Ocwen's acquisition of Residential Capital's platform and the Ally servicing rights. The company expects a doubling in non-GSE loans by year's end and a 700 bp increase in operating margins. Sister company Altisource Asset Management (AAMC +23.2%). (PR)

  • SWK

    Stanley Black & Decker (SWK -2.9%) slips on a muddy Q1, beating on a per share basis but...

    Stanley Black & Decker (SWK -2.9%) slips on a muddy Q1, beating on a per share basis but coming up shy on revenue. Net earnings fell 33% Y/Y on higher expenses and tighter margins. Gross margin narrowed to 36.6% from 37.6% as input costs rose 4.1%. Its construction and do-it-yourself segment, the largest by revenue, reported a 1.7% increase in sales, while profit jumped 14%. Earnings in its security segment were down 21%, while the industrial segments earnings tumbled 30%.

     
     
     
     
    | 3:30 PM
  • CSCO

    Checks indicate BroadSoft (BSFT +4.9%) is taking part in a tech collaboration with Google that...

    Checks indicate BroadSoft (BSFT +4.9%) is taking part in a tech collaboration with Google that involves resellers, system integrators, and managed service providers, says William Blair, giving a nice lift to the provider of VoIP/unified communications software. The collaboration could have something to do with Google's reported efforts to unify its many communications/messaging products. Q1 results are due on May 6; 24.5% of the float was shorted as of March 28.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:27 PM

    The Homebuilder ETF (XHB +1.2%) gains after PulteGroup (PHM +5.5%) reported Q1 closings up 23%,...

    The Homebuilder ETF (XHB +1.2%) gains after PulteGroup (PHM +5.5%) reported Q1 closings up 23%, with the average selling price up 10%. Meritage Homes (MTH +1.1%) yesterday reported a 17% increase in prices, while Ryland Group (RYL +6.7%) last night said its average price rose 8.2%. "Housing demand is greater than the supply of homes available for sale in many of the areas where we operate," says Meritage CEO Steven Hilton.

    The flow of key farm products (NYSEARCA:DBA) to the world from North and South America,...

    The flow of key farm products (NYSEARCA:DBA) to the world from North and South America, highlighted by congestion at Brazilian ports and limited selling of crops by U.S. farmers, will keep global grain supplies tight despite expectations for big harvests later this year, Bunge (BG +6.5%) says after its Q1 report showed a 16% jump in agribusiness sales to $10.77B.

    Reliance Steel (RS -4%) slips today after its Q1 misses on all fronts. Net earnings fell 28% Y/Y as the metals-processing company saw prices decline for all its major products and sold fewer tons. The company also warns that it expects global economic and political uncertainty to continue to challenge industrial growth in the current quarter, with only slight improvements in demand amid weak pricing. It lowers its Q2 EPS forecast to between $1.10 to $1.20, below Street estimates of $1.51.

    GrafTech International (GTI +2%) moves up in spite of posting a mixed Q1, missing on the top line but beating on its bottom line EPS. but the company cut 2013 EBITDA guidance. Net sales increased 5% Y/Y, driven by higher graphite electrode volumes which had significant customer de-stocking. But the company warned that, as a result of declining economic and steel data, it didn't see markets improving for the full year and guides down. It now expects to earn between $165M to $195M, reflecting weak demand for graphite electrodes.

    If Verizon (VZ +2.2%) is serious about buying Vodafone's (VOD +2.8%) Verizon Wireless stake, $100B isn't going to cut it, thinks Jefferies. The firm values the stake at $121B based on a 7.7x estimated EV/EBITDA multiple for the March 2014 fiscal year, and notes a Sunday Times article discussed a possible valuation of $135B (others have suggested $115B). There's also the question of how keen Vodafone is on selling when its stake has been appreciating considerably, and is now yielding giant cash distributions. On the flip side, a sale could fuel a massive M&A-driven expansion into growth markets. (Reuters report)

    On Assignment (ASGN +11.6%) soars after raising guidance and handily beating top and bottom line estimates. The company now sees Q2 EPS of $0.27-0.29 on revenues of between $410-414M (analysts see $0.26 per share on sales of $401.98M). Gross margins fell to 29.1% from 33.6% but CFO Edward Pierce told BofA's Sara Gubins that ASGN should still hit the lower end of its gross margins range (30.3%) for the full year. The company also said it had not factored in its lower cost of debt in its upbeat Q2 guidance. (transcript)
